0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Rabies, Postexposure; Prophylaxis: 20 International Units/kg IM for 1 dose in conjunction with rabies vaccine

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: Rabies, Postexposure; Prophylaxis: 20 International Units/kg IM for 1 dose in conjunction with rabies vaccine

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: repeated doses, should not be administered once vaccine treatment has been initiated; potential for interference with maximum active immunity expected from vaccine (Imogam(R) Rabies-HT)

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• bleeding disorders, preexisting; may result in bleeding complications due to intramuscular route of vaccine
  • concomitant use with live vaccines, such as measles, mumps, polio, or rubella; should not be used within 3 months of rabies immunoglobulin
  • human plasma product; infectious agent risk, including viruses and theoretical risk of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
  • intramuscular use only; should not be administered intravenously because of potential for serious reactions
  • isolated immunoglobulin A deficiency; may increase risk for developing antibodies to IgA and for anaphylactic reactions with subsequent administration of IgA-containing blood products
  • repeated doses, should not be administered once vaccine treatment has been initiated; potential for interference with maximum active immunity expected from vaccine (HyperRab(TM) S/D)
  • systemic allergic reaction to human immune globulin preparation, history
  • thrombocytopenia, preexisting; may result in bleeding complications due to intramuscular route of vaccine
  • report suspected transmission of infection from HyperRAB(TM) S/D to Talecris Biotherapeutics at 1-800-520-2807 and from Imogam(R) Rabies-HT to Sanofi Pasteur at 1-800-822-2463

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

2.title: Moderate
2.mono:
• Measles Virus Vaccine, Live (probable)
  • Mumps Virus Vaccine, Live (probable)
  • Rotavirus Vaccine, Live (probable)
  • Rubella Virus Vaccine, Live (probable)
  • Smallpox Vaccine (probable)
  • Varicella Virus Vaccine (probable)

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Erythema (conventional formulation, 63%; heat-treated formulation, 25%), Injection site pain (conventional formulation, 100%; heat-treated formulation, 50%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (conventional formulation, 50%; heat-treated formulation, 69%)
Serious
Immunologic:Anaphylaxis (rare)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: Following intramuscular administration, rabies immune globulin provides immediate passive antibodies for a short period of time. This protects the patient until the patient can produce active antibodies from the rabies vaccine.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intramuscular
  • if anatomically possible, thoroughly infiltrate the full dose in the area around the wound; any remaining volume may be given IM (using a separate needle) at a site distant from vaccine administration; for HyperRAB S/D(R), may administer the remainder into the deltoid muscle of the upper arm or lateral thigh muscle; avoid the gluteal region due to risk of injury to sciatic nerve
  • do not mix in same syringe as vaccine

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: clinical signs and symptoms of rabies, rabies antibody titer

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• HyperRAB S/D
    Intramuscular Solution: 150 IU/ML
  • Imogam Rabies-HT
    Intramuscular Solution: 150 IU/ML

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to avoid vaccines up to 3 mo after receiving this drug, unless approved by healthcare professional.
  • Despite screening and testing, human plasma products carry a risk of transmitting infectious agents. Risks and benefits should be discussed with patient by healthcare professional.
  • This drug may cause headache or fever.
